description.narrative:
PELUM will be the lead partner in terms of the implementation of the proposed campaign against the amendment of article 26 of the constitution of Uganda that would remove the requirement for prior and prompt compensation of project affected persons.
Under the current Article 26 (2), no person shall be compulsorily deprived of property or any interest in or right over property of any description except where it#s for public use or in the interest of defense, public safety, public order, public morality or public health. Furthermore, the said compulsory acquisition should happen after prompt payment of fair and adequate compensation, prior to the taking of possession or acquisition of the property. It also provides for the right to seek legal redress by any aggrieved person.
In the proposed amendment, government is seeking powers to deposit compensation for any compulsorily acquired land to court. The proposal seeks to empower government to take over the land and in case of any dispute; the compensation award will be deposited pending determination of the dispute. Additionally, it provides powers to the property owner to access the compensation awarded at any time during the dispute resolution process. Lastly, it empowers Parliament to make a law toprescribe the timeframe within which disputes arising out of compensation will be resolved. Government#s justification is that the said requirement stands in the way of her infrastructure projects because some people demand exorbitant amounts of money which not only inflates the project costs but also stalls these projects. Justification Besides this proposal being against international and regional standards on the right to property ownership, it also puts at stake the lives and livelihoods of 70 percent of Ugandans who depend on their lands for a living # most are women, the poor and vulnerable.

participating-org.narrative: Founded in 1995 by civil society organisations in east central and southern Africa to facilitate networking and learning on ecological land use management among civil society organizations in the region. After its launch in 1995, PELUM Uganda was hostedby member organizations including Environmental Alert, Integrated Rural Development Initiatives and Community Development Resource Network, with a staff from the host institution allocated the responsibility to coordinate PELUM (50% of their staff time) but personnel costs fully paid by the host. PELUM also took advantage of the legal status of the host, also used policies and financial systems of the host In 2006, PELUM registered with the NGO Board and also with the registrar of companies in 2007. In the same year (2006), PELUM employed a full time staff and acquired office space (mid Sept 2006). The coordinator was mainly supported by volunteers (2006 – 2007). Policies we developed and approved by the board in the 1st half of 2007. Audits are done every calendar year. Currently has 3 fulltime staff and 2 volunteers, membership, programs and funding partners are steadily increasing. PELUM has conducted gender workshops for members, has considers gender in its M<(>&<)>E work as well as its HR policy
